document.docAuthor: Valdés, Ángel, Lundsten, Lonny & Wilson, Nerida G.
document.docTitle: Dendronotus claguei Valdés & Lundsten & Wilson 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Five new deep-sea species of nudibranchs (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia: Cladobranchia) from the Northeast Pacific

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Five new deep-sea species of nudibranchs (Gastropoda: Heterobranchia: Cladobranchia) from the Northeast Pacific

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype : Alarcón Rise , Gulf of California , Northeast Pacific Ocean (23.4549, -108.485405),
2369 m
depth, ROV Doc Ricketts (dive 394),
24 Apr 2012
, 7 mm preserved length ( LACM 3554 ), GenBank accession number:
MH 756144
( H3 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratype : Alarcón Rise , Gulf of California , Northeast Pacific Ocean (23.4549, -108.485405),
2368.8 m
depth, ROV Doc Ricketts (dive 394),
24 Apr 2012
, 18 mm preserved length, dissected
.

Description. Body long, narrow, with 4-6 pairs of simple, elongate, dorso-lateral cerata ( Fig. 2C ). Velum composed of 4 narrow and elongate papillae. Rhinophores with very elongate stalks. Rhinophoral sheaths with 4 elongate, simple papillae on distal edges, the innermost papilla being much larger than the other three. Rhinophoral clubs elongate, with 11 simple lamellae. Color uniformly translucent white with some internal organs visible through the body wall as beige or yellowish areas.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 9. Drawings of the internal anatomy of the paratype of
Dendronotus claguei
sp. nov.
(LACM 3555). A. General view of the internal anatomy. B. Reproductive system. Abbreviations: am, ampulla; bb, buccal bulb; bc, copulatrix; cns, central nervous system; dd, deferent duct; dg, digestive gland; es, esophagus; fgc, female gland complex; i, intestine; pe, penis; rm, retractor muscle; sg, salivary gland; sr, seminal receptacle; vg, vagina.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology. This species was collected at 2369 m depth on an inactive hydrothermal chimney of the Alarcón Rise, approximately 53 nautical miles east of Cabo Pulmo, Baja California Sur , Mexico ( Fig. 1 ). Although the inactive chimney itself was mostly devoid of life, other organisms seen in the vicinity of the collection site included
Aldrovandia
sp. (halosaurid fishes),
Biremis
sp. (terebellid polychaete), Bonellidae (echiuran), Galatheidae (squat lobster), Liparidae (snail fishes), Synallactidae (holothurian), and dense Xenophyophoroidea (benthic foraminifera).

Phylogenetic position. According to the phylogenetic analyses here conducted ( Fig. 6 ),
Dendronotus claguei
sp. nov.
appears to be sister to a clade containing several specimens identified as
D. robustus
and also including
D. patricki
.

Etymology. The species is named in honor of David A. Clague, MBARI Senior Scientist and Volcanologist. Dave was the Chief Scientist of the expedition to Alarcón Rise, where the specimens were collected.

Remarks.
Dendronotus claguei
sp. nov.
is morphologically very different from most other species of
Dendronotus
. The only exception is the Atlantic deep-sea species
D. comteti Valdés & Bouchet, 1998
, described from a hydrothermal vent site at 1685 m depth in the mid-Atlantic Ridge, which also has a simple dorso-lateral cerata, with no branching pattern. Additionally, both
D. comteti
and
D. claguei
sp. nov.
have similarly shaped rachidian teeth, but in
D. claguei
sp. nov.
they are more triangular than in
D. comteti
. Unfortunately, the reproductive anatomy, external coloration and sequence data of
D. comteti
remain unknown, therefore it could not be included in the phylogenetic analyses.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 10. SEMs of the radula and jaws of the paratype of
Dendronotus claguei
sp. nov.
(LACM 3555). A. Radular teeth. B. Jaw masticatory border.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Dendronotus claguei
sp. nov.
is the only Eastern Pacific species of
Dendronotus
with a uniform white background color and simple dorso-lateral cerata. The only other species of
Dendronotus
reported from deepwaters in the Northeast Pacific is
D. patricki Stout, Wilson, and Valdés, 2011
, described from 1819 m depth in the Monterey Canyon, California . These two species are easily differentiated by their radular and reproductive anatomy. Although
D. claguei
sp. nov.
has a triangular rachidian tooth with 11–13 sharp, similar sized denticles on each side, running from the tip of the cups to the base, in
D. patricki
the teeth are elongate with about 20 denticles on each side, and the cusp is clearly differentiated from the rest of the tooth, with very small denticles. Additionally,
D. patricki
has simple lateral teeth, devoid of denticles, whereas
D. claguei
sp. nov.
has up to 10 apical, sharp denticles on the lateral teeth. The reproductive system of
D. patricki
has a very elongate prostate and a large bursa copulatrix in relation to the width of the vagina, whereas in
D. claguei
sp. nov.
the prostate is much shorter and the bursa copulatrix is not much wider than the vagina. Externally,
D. claguei
sp. nov.
is characterized by having a uniformly white body with simple lateral appendages, while
D. patricki
is reddish brown, with ramified dorsal appendages in a fan-shaped branching pattern.
